div1.p: This report details the Army's mosquito control operations around Camp Meade, Maryland.

div1.head: Report: The Activities of the United States Public Health Service in the Camp Meade Extra Cantonment [sic.] Zone, January 1918 to June 30, 1919
div1.p:
REPORT OF THE ACTIVITIES OF THE UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
IN THE CAMP MEADE EXTRA CANTONMENT ZONE
JANUARY 1918 to JUNE 30, 1919.

MAJOR PERSONNEL
Assistant Surgeon GeneralH. R. CarterIn supervisory charge.
SurgeonE. A. SweetIn charge May 2, 1918,
to August 30th, 1918.
Associate Sanitary EngineerL. M. FisherMay 7th, to Aug. 30, 1918.
Associate Sanitary EngineerSol PincusIn charge April 1, 1919
to June 30th, 1919.
Assistant Sanitary EngineerH. F. TaitApril 3, 1919 to June
30th, 1919.
Acting Assistant Surgeon and
Deputy State Health Officer.W. C. StoneJan. 14, 1918 to June
30th, 1919.
GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

Camp Meade is located in Anne Arundel County, Maryland about
equidistant from the District of Columbia, Baltimore and Annapolis, and less
than twenty five miles from each of these places. The main camp was con-
structed during June - September 1917, as a barracks encampment for National
Army units. It had an average capacity for 50,000 men and was thus one of
the largest o the army camps. The close proximity of this great canton-
ment to these highly important centers of the Nation's war activities gave
the sanitary relations of the camp and zone an extremely large significance.
In fact it was soon demonstrated, the camp treated the above cities as within
their zone; laborers and materials being regularly obtained from Baltimore,
- 2 -
while the soldiers on leave visited mostly that city, with the officers
showing partiality for Washington. A very small increase, comparatively, in
activities in the immediately surrounding country resulted from the camp's ex-
istence. From its very commencement the camp, even during the period of
construction, provided for all the legitimate needs of its forces in material
and social ways, within the camp. Unlike the usual occurence, this camp
did not produce the construction of new living or amusement facilities in the
nearby section, therefore, not even one well equipped rooming house or eating
place was erected in the contiguous territory. Odenton, a small unincorpora-
ted village on the eatern edge of the reservation and the town of Laurel of
1500 population received the impetus only to erect a dozen or so cottages and
rent out some furnished rooms to the few brought there by the camp. With the
fine transportation facilities of the Washington, Baltimore, and Annapolis
Electric Line, which operates a regular service into the camp and the Penn-
sylvania Railroad on the eastern side and of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad
on the northwestern side the opportunity to spend their leisure time in the
large and more attractive cities was generally availed of by the sojourners
at the camp.

The problem of establishing a protective health zone for the en-
campment at Meade could then be viewed in two ways. The Sanitary Zone to
be extended to include the cities of Washington, Baltimore and Annapolis
which had a close relationship to the camp and where much room for sanitary
improvements and additional public health control existed, especially with
the tendency to decreased health forces and extreme congestion of population
caused by war conditions. The other plan would be to restrict the Federal
- 3 -
extra-cantonment health efforts to the small section directly contiguous to
the reservation, where in the distinctly rural section only a few villages and
two small towns were located. The first plan was probably long considered
but beset with difficulties of the involved relationships and authorities of
the several local and state Boards of Health that it affected, was finally
given up for the second method.

The sanitary zone about Camp Meade that was established in the Spring
of 1918 was defined to include approximately the area five miles from the
boundary of the government reservation. This area was about 125 square
miles nearly all within Anne Arundel County, small sectors extending into
Howard and Prince Georges Counties. The following communities and institu-
tions are within this area.

The above population is the estimated war time population in the zone,
which is scarcely an increase of 20 per cent over the normal average number
- 4 -
of persone. About 20 per cent of this population are colored.

In this area the principal industries are farming, (mostly truck
produce) vegetable canning and cotton weaving. Cotton weaving plants are
located at Savage and Laurel, while nine canneries are scattered through the
zone, at Odenton, Jessup, Woodwardville, etc. Race tracks at Bowie and Laurel
brin an influx of thousands of persons into the zone for short periods during t
the racing seasons. Close to Odenton is the Naval Academy Junction where
passengers from Washington transfer for Annapolis. A large car shop and re-
pair station is maintained at this place by the Washington, Baltimore and
Annapolis Electric Line.
HISTORICAL

Two years previous to the establishment of Camp Meade, the entire
county of Anne Arundel was made the subject of an intensive sanitary survey
jointly carried on by the United States Public Health Service. Public Health
Bulletin No. 94. The findings of the survey in the rural sections showed
that there were 4,800 insanitary privies used for excreta disposal with only
576 homes having sanitary types of privies or water closets. “At 2,625 ( or
48.41 per cent) of the homes having water supply on the premises, the source
of the water supply was apparently exposed to pollution with human excreta
or other refuse matter, and was regarded by the inspector as unsafe.”
At Annapolis, 300 homes with privies were found, and the public water supply
found to be open to pollution. A general educational campaign on disease
prevention was conducted during the survey and partial improvements were ob-
tained in sanitation including the extension of the sewer system and the in-
stallation of chlorination of the public water supply at Annapolis.

A study of the malaria conditions in the County was made at the same
- 5 -
time by Assistant Surgeon Derivaux. His report stated that conditions were
found favorable to Anopheles Mosquito production for five months of the year,
the middle of May to the first weeks of October He found the Anopheles Mos-
quito common throughout the county the Anopheles punctipennis far more plen-
tiful than the Anopheles Quadrimaculatus and Anopheles Crucians. Though cases
of malaria as gathered from the physicians in the county are not numerous, the
conclusion from the study was that definite danger existed for future periods
when the enormous supply of malaria carrying mosquitoes might obtain access
to a moderately generous gametocyte supply.

At the time of the establishment of Camp Meade in June 1917, there
was a State Deputy Health Officer who had jurisdiction in the three counties
of Howard, Prince Georges and Anne Arundel. A local part time county
health officer was located at Annapolis and a part time municipal health
officers at Laurel and Annapolis. Unofficial organizations were doing active
health work in the vicinity, e.g. the Maryland Society for the Prevention of
Tuberculosis.

The general sanitary conditions of the area around Camp Meade before its
construction can be summarized as follows; insanitary “ E ” type privies pre-
vailing universally, water supply in rural sections from shallow dug wells or
springs, unprotected from surface contaminations, the public water supply for
the town of Laurel receiving treatment, but the operation of the plant poor,
the sewage from the House of Correction and from Savage Mills entering Little
Patuxent

ACTIVITIES OF U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE IN CAMP MEADE ZONE
1917 - 1918.

During 1917, the State Department of Health provided 5 inspectors
- 6 -
(medical students) to assist the Deputy State Health Officer in the sanita-
tion of the region about Camp Meade. A survey of the conditions at Laurel and
of the rural section within three miles of camp was made. 600 homes were
canvassed during that season. Efforts to obtain definite improvements in
the sanitary facilities at the dwellings and stores were in part very diffi-
cult and was unproductive. The area about Odenton, was freed of open back
surface privies, and flyproof concrete vaults were installed at every home.
The railroads were obtained to provide satisfactory chemical closets at their
stations at Odenton and Annapolis Junction. During the latter part of the
year the student inspectors were replaced by a full time inspector who directed
the sanitation of the privies and wells. An interchange of reports of
communicable diseases with the Camp Surgeon was arranged to cover the area
about the camp and the reservation itself.

In 1918, the State Sanitary force maintained in this district was
composed of the Deputy Health and two assistants. Inspections of privies,
garbage collection and protection of water supplies was continued. During
this period a modern sewage treatment plant including primary and secondary
sedimentation, trickling filters and chlorination was installed at the State
House of Correction at Jessup, the final effluent of which entered the drain-
age shed for the Camp Meade water supply. A sewerage system and treatment
plant was arranged for the town of Savage, whose drainage also entered the raw
water of the camp, the proposition being placed well under way and the treat-
ment plant, consisting of double sedimentation tank and chlorination later
put into operation, in 1919.

In this year 91 concrete pit privies and about 500 bucket privies
were installed. Nearly 800 homes and stores were visited. 18 schools
- 7 -
were kept under observation and lectures presented on public health subjects.

Cases of communicable diseases as reported by the practising physicians
were regularly visited by the deputy state health officer and assistants.
An outbreak of 60 cases of small pox at Savage and 15 in Laurel occured in 1918,
quarantine and guards were employed and the outbreak confined. The influenza
pandemic swept through this region striking practically every home both in
rural and urban sections, leaving its wake of suffering and misery. Only
limited medical aid could be furnished to this region, due to the enormous
demands for assistance upon the State Department of Health.
Preliminary survey by Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter

At the request of the Maryland State Department of Health, Assistant
Surgeon General H. R. Carter was sent in August 1917 to make a malaria survey
of Camp Meade and vicinity. In this report of the survey dated August 13,
1917, Dr. Carter records that the State Board of Health house to house census
just then completed demonstrated that malaria occurred in some places in the
Camp Meade Zone but is rare, though some years previously the disease was
reported generally prevalent. The significant features of the topography
were found to be the unusually large number of side marshes and hillside seep-
age outcrops, with a large number of small but permanent streams in a region
which must be classified as very sandy but is apparently considerably under-
laid with an impervious clay-gravel and ironstone strata. It was also noted
that the stream beds would be subject to rapid filling up with sand and the
resultant overflows produces favorable breeding areas for anopheles. As
- 8 -
regards the prevalence of Anopheles breeding in this area, it was seen that the
production of Anopheles was general, even profuse in places and that except
in a few locations only Anopheles punctipennis were developed from the lar-
vae.discovered. Anopheles quadrimaculatus and Anopheles Crucians were found
in the larger pools in the vicinity of Odenton and the Naval Academy Junction
and at Woodwardville near which places the only instances of malaria were
reported. The general recommendation was that drainage of the breeding
areas was readily practicable and should be the method pursued except in the
case of one or two large ponds.
Anti Malaria Operations - Season of 1918.

Actual mosquito drainage was not commenced in this zone until May
1918, when a Medical Officer and Sanitary Engineer from the Service arrived.
Labor crews obtained from the Maryland House of Correction were started upon
the ditching work May 2. Anopheles were found breeding rather profurely in
the zone at this time The territory outlined to be covered by anti-malaria
measures was approximately 20 square miles. The first ditching was begun
in the area northeast of the Base Hospital where the breeding of Anopheles
was very large and near to occupied sections of the camp.

By the end of June approximately 12 square miles of the control area
had been completed as regards initial construction and the following amount of work
had been accomplished

DRAINAGE WORK MAY 2ND TO JUNE 30TH, 1918.
Seepage Ditches Dug28,000 linear feet.
Stream Channesl Cleaned22,400 " "
New Stream Channels Cut2,800 " "
Large Drainage Ditches Dug2,450 " "
Old Ditches Trimmed and Cleaned7,300 " "
24 Inch Tile Drain Cleaned500 " "
Fill Made600 Cubic Feet.
Total Linear feet of ditching performed63,450 linear feet.
Labor Costs, Average Crew of 26 men.$4,800.00

The drainage operations were continued for two more months in which
the sections to the east and south were treated. Scarcely any breeding
whatever was discovered in sections where drainage and stream clearing had
been accomplished and the application of oil was seldom considered necessary.
Arrangements were made with the Camp Surgeon whereby the camp sanitary de-
tachment would keep oil sprayers available for such areas in the extra-can-
tonment zone requiring oiling.

The drainage accomplished from July 1 to the close of the season's
work on August 30 is summarized as follows:

DRAINAGE WORK JULY 1ST to AUGUST 30, 1919.
New Ditches Dug43,000 linear feet.
Old Ditch Or Stream Trained.18,000 " "
Fill Vade4,800 cubic feet.
Total Labor Costs$ 5,400.00

The following report by Associate Sanitary Engineer L. M. Fisher
gives the description of the areas and the account of the work accomplished
during the season of 1918.

REPORT ON MALARIA CONTROL WORK AT CAMP MEADE EXTRA CANTONMENT ZONE
SEASON OF 1918, ASSOCIATE SANITARY ENGINEER L. M. FISHER

The areas in which work was done in Camp Meade extra-cantonment zone
in 1918 are indicated by shading on the accompanying may (Map No. 1 ). They
are as follows:

A-Area northwest of the base hospital in the vicinity of the George
Junior Republic
B-North of base hospital
C-Northeast of base hospital-Clark swamp
D-Valley of a tributary of Severn River on the Baltimore Boulevard
E-Headquarters of tributaries of Severn River east of new signal
corps camp.
F-Vicinity about Odenton and Naval Academy Junction
G-Vicinity about Woodwardville opposite rifle range
H-Area west of Portland opposite Remount Station.

Between areas C and D additional work remains to be done, at
present it is beyond a mile from any barracks. It is rumored however, that
quarters for 15,000 troops are to be created on high ground near this corner
of the camp.
Some work also remains to be done between areas D and E.

Between F and G is a large area in which no work has been done.
It is not close enough, however, to any sleeping quarters to make any material
difference except when troops are encamped on the rifle range. If the
rifle range is to be protected considerable work will be necessary to extend
the area F southeastward as far as the W.B.andi Railway tracks. The are is
low, subject to overflow from the Patuxent, contains pools in flood channels
and some marshy land. The army authorities have not done the work inside the
camp necessary to protect the range.

Between G and H is a large area in now way effecting the camp at
present.

North of H and west of A is an area far from the camp and effecting
only the population about Annapolis Junction, or travellers making connection
here.
Description of Areas.

In area A there is a swimming pool formed by a dam on a spring fed
stream. The pool has an area of about two acres. The level was lowered
so as to draw most of the water out of the vegetation along the borders.
The edges were cleaned. The pond is well stocked with fish. Two spring
fed tributaries enter the pond. They flow through a wooded swamp. Their
channels were deepened and seepage interception ditcher dug where necessary.
All this area was unwatered.

Area B contains streams flowing through partly wooded areas and marshes.
The stream beds were found obstructed and containing pools in which breeding
was observed under grassy banks and where masses of rootlets afforded protection.
Breeding was observed in hoof prints in the marsh and in small pools

The edges of the streams were trimmed so as to permit the small fish
to attack the larvae. The necessary seepage ditches were installed in the
marsh.

Area C contained a rather extensive wooded swamp heavily covered with
marsh alder and some streams. ( Clark Swamp )

Seepage ditches were constructed in the swamp and the edges of the
stream bed trimmed. On account of its proximity to the hospital the ditches
in this area should be examined and put into conditions before the breeding
season. Some of the seepage ditches are rather deep and enter flowing sand
strata. If the season should be wet some difficulty may be encountered in
maintenance.

Area D extends along a tributary of the Severn River having a flat
gradient and wooded for the most part. The wooded areas frequently con-
tained swamps which were controlled by deepening the main stream bed and
constructing seepage ditches where necessary. The concrete box culvert
carrying the Baltimore Boulevard over this stream is too high so that
no sufficient fall could be obtained for some of the seepage ditches. This
area also contains a wet weather stream crossing the boulevard west of the
main tributary. In the bed profusely breeding pools were found. It can
be expected that each scouring rain will leave such pools.

Area E contains the headwaters of many small tributaries of the
Severn River. These tributaries flow through wooded, marshy country.
In two places artificial pools were a formed by road crossings.
- 13 -
The main channesl were deepened where any existed and new ones dug else-
where where necessary. Many seepage ditches were dug. This area on
account of its proximity to the new Signal Corps Camp is very important
but profuse breeding was not observed in it.

Area F lying about Odenton and Naval Academy Junction contains
two artificial ponds and the headwater areas of small tributaries.

One pond - that used by the W. B. & A Electric Railway Company as a
reservoir for its fire pump - was lowered, its edges cleaned and stocked
with top minnows.

The other - an abandoned sand pit - was treated by cleaning the edges.
Top minnows were present here and others added.
A third pond-formerly a borrow pit-was drained.

The stream channels were deepened as much as necessary to drain seep-
age ditches where railroad culverts did not prevent.

In a portion o the area agricultural drain tile was laid evidently
by a real estate development company. Millow roots entering the main 18-
drain having reduced its free sectional area approximately 75% so that
after rains pools are formed. The maintenance work should include pro-
vision for removing obstructions to the inlets after rains.

Area G, near Woodwardville, contains a number of ponds. The prin-
cipal one was caused by the P.R.R. embarkment placed across what appears
to have been a former stream bed just north of Patuxent Station. A rather
deep and wide channel was out parallel to the railroad embarkment running
north. It is probable that high waters will considerably damage this
channel. A branch leads westward to a low area in the woods.

East of the railroad some of the old ditches were opened up and
on the Anderson farm southeast of the church a new channel was dug for a
- 14 -
stream that spread over a flat area adjacent to the river.

Additional work needs to be done in this area to protect the rifle
range but unless the swamp in the camp very much nearer the range is
drained, the work in the outlying areas will not be justified.

Area H contains principally streams having obstructed channels in
which pools form, and some abandoned ore pits and swamp land adjacent to the
Patuxent.

The stream channels were cleaned. The ore pits lying south of the
dirt road to Laurel and west of the gravel pits drained. The swamp which
is north of the Laurel road was controlled by diverting the stream overflow-
ing it.

CLIMATOLOGICAL DATA - CAMP MEADE ZONE
MONTHLY PRECIPITATION, AND MAXIMUM, MINIMUM AND MEAN TEMPERATURE
LAUREL, MARYLAND, 1918.
TEMPERATURE

(inches)MaximumMinimumMean
(Degrees Fahrenheit)
.............................................................
January4.2552-1021.6

June2.43954469.2

September3.6736
October0.95842857.8

December4.95681539.2

Killing Frosts recorded at Laurel, Maryland.
1918, Spring April 6
Autumn October 9.
ACTIVITIES OF THE U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE SEASON OF 1919.

When the Service anti-malaria operations were discontinued on the
30th of August, 1918, there remained in the extra cantonment zone the State
Deputy Health Officer in whose sanitary district the Camp Meade Zone lay.
The work thus continued was chiefly the visiting of the reported cases of
the more important communicable diseases and the inspection of sanitary
conditions at Odenton.

The Public Health Service was again requested to undertake anti-
malaria work in the vicinity of the Camp and on April 1st, sanitary engineers
were detailed to supervise and expend the necessary efforts to prevent the
breeding of Anopheles Mosquitoes likely to reach the Camp. Besides the
strictly anti-malaria measures at once instituted, other matters of sanitary
significance to the camp were pursued.

The sewage treatment plant at the State Prison at Jessup whose effluent
passes into the raw water for the camp, was frequently inspected and the
operation and chlorination checked. The sewage plant at Savage, similarly a
situated was only placed into operation at about the time of the closing of
the station. The proposition of providing a sewerage and a public water
supply system for Odenton by connection with the camp facilities was ta
up with the Camp and State sanitary officials. Conferences were ha
studies undertaken to determine the feasibility of this improveme
proposition is now left ith the State Health Department who will determine
the desirability of proceding further.

Inspections of the sanitary conditions usually together with the
- 17 -
Deputy State Health Officer were made of the stores, dwellings etc., at
Odenton with respect to the conditions of privies, garbage, manure and water
supply, and orders issued and some improvements obtained. Privies found
breeding flies were treated successfully with disinfectant. A few well
supplies were examined bacteriologically. The temporary railroad con-
struction camps at Odenton and Woodwardville were required to maintain their
privies flyproof and their general premises in sanitary shape.
MALARIA CONTROL OPERATIONS 1919.

The areas in which the control operations were undertaken for the pre-
vention of the breeding of Anopheles Mosquitoes and the consequent spread of
malaria were essentially the same in which the previous season's work was
accomplished. The nature and characteristics of these areas are described in
the reports of the former work. The control work for the new season was soon
found to require much more than the straightening and recleaning of old ditches
previously put in; notably the areas north and east of the base hospital and
in the vicinity of Odenton, much new construction of drainage facilities had to
be made, amounting practically to first treatment.

The first work undertaken this season, Section 1, Job 1(see map
dated June 30, 1919) was the area immediately to the east of the Base Hos-
pital. At the time of the commencement of the ditching on April 15, only
Culex larvae were found breeding, but by the middle of May the larvae of An-
opheles species were discovered rather generally distributed throughout the
areas into which control operations were being pushed. It was not, however, until after
- 18 -
the first week of June, that other species of Anopheles than Anopheles
Punctipennis were located, these latter in the warmer, grassy ponds.

A significant condition noted in three instances during the progress of
the work was the sudden very abundant prevalence of Culex eggs in ponds and
temporarily impounded streams shortly after the labor crew commenced working
on that section.

The drainage work was carried on to the very close of the fiscal year
1919, when all service activities in this zone were discontinued. Arrange-
ments with the Camp Sanitary Office for the maintenance and oiling necessary
for these drainage areas during the remainder of the breeding season. were made
SUMMARY OF DRAINAGE OPERATIONS APRIL 15 to JUNE 30, 1919.

row.cell: Number of days actually doing construction
Linear feet of reditching and stream clearing
Ponds drains Four total area square feet

div1.p: SECTION 1 BASE HOSPITAL DISTRICT.
Job. 1 Rogues Harbor Run.

Location - North east of Base Hospital. Area extending south
into the government reservation, 400 yards from base hospital and to County
Road to Jessup 1/2 mile in length.

The area commencing in the Clark property extending north
- 19 -
composed of farm and densely brush covered land contains the heaviest
constant spring outflow met with in this region. The main channel was ex-
tending 2598 feet was reditched and deepened its entire length, 540 feet of
new channel dug in straightening the course. Heavy sliding occurring on the
second section of this ditch towards the eastern side necessitated the in-
stallation of approximately 300 feet of blind ditches. The unusual outcrop
of spring seepage at varying levels called attention to the irregularity of the
contour of the ground water level. Prolific breeding of Culex but few
Anopheles larvae were found at the time of the commencement of the work..
New ditching linear feet6,790 linear feet.
Old ditch and stream training5,200 " "
Brush square yards28,700 square yards.
Work Commenced April 15, 1919.
Work Finished May 8, 1919.
Labor cost 355 man days$ 1136.00
Supervision175.00

Section 1, Job 2.
Brown Swamp North West of Base Hospital.

This area extending within the reservation had previously been in-
completely drained. Due to the profuse breeding of Anopheles it was deemed
advisable to complete this drainage at once to the Dorsey Run, a branch of
the Little Patuxent River. The failure to complete this job during the
previous season was evidently due to the fact that it lay within the old reser-
vations though its character and proximity to the base hospital buildings still con-
stituted a probable menace.
- 20 -
Linear feet of new ditching3,855
Linear feet of reditching7,165
Square yards of brush clearing11,129
Two ponds drained 79' x 45' and 50 x 14 feet respectively.
Labor cost 220 man days$ 704.00
Supervision99.00
Section 1 Job 3.
National Junior Republic Swamp and Pond.

This area lying to the northwest of the Base Hospital was characterized
by the density of the heavy timber growths and the great mass of impounded
water in a mucky and sandy soil. This presented as difficult a drainage
proposition as any in the areas treated. A pond approximately two acres in
extent caused by the damming of the lower sections of the water course materially
assisted in maintaining the supersaturated conditions of the ground. A re-
taining wall was built at the pond head to prevent the constant sliding of
the muck and permitted the by-passing of the drainage from above the pond
through two ditches; at the same time reclaiming about 500 square yards of
swamp land and making possible the maintenance of a constant minimum water area.
No breeding has since been discovered in this section.
Linear feet ditching, mostly through heavy roots11,293
Square yards of brush clearing5,300
Retaining wall built 40' long 8' x 4'
Labor cost 205 man days$ 656.00
Supervision81.00
Section 1 Job 4.

This drainage work consisted of the relief of impounded roadside
gutter water and a small pond along the north side of the highway between
the bridge and Dorsey Run and Annapolis Junction. There was an intense
amount of breeding of both Anopheles and Culex in these water areas. Approx-
imately 1,000 feet of ditching and 600 square yards of brush clearing were
performed to provide drainage for this section.
Labor cost 20 man days$ 64.00
Supervision6.00
Section 2 Franklin District Job 1.

North and northeast of the Franklin Cantonment consisted of a series
of highway borrow pits, 11 in number, necessitating a fill of 9720 cubic
feet and the ditching of 915 feet of road gutter.
Labor Cost 36 man days$ 115.20
Supervision13.50

Franklin Section northeast of reservation. This proposition consisted
a tri forked branch of the Severn drainage system, mostly of small spring
fed blind water run ways, frequently blocked by sandy ridges or humpbacks
and in the wooded sections oblitereated by masses of driftwood.
Linear feet of ditching2,258
Square yards of brush clearing1,050
Labor Coast 68 man days$ 217.60
Supervision30.50

This area lying to the east of the Franklin cantonment constituted
the largest single drainage area treated in the zone. Had funds been avail-
able, this area would have been considered worthy of treatment similar to
the Rogues Harbor Run Section 1, Job 1, that is complete straightening
and recoursing of channels with the development of a more uniform drainage
system. A pond 50 x 80 feet and 26 feet deep at the reservation line was
drained.
Linear feet of ditching14,376.
Square yards or brush clearing12,000
Labor cost 142 man days$ 454.40
Supervision86.00

Small swamps northeast of barracks at Franklin draining into the
reservation under the W.B. & A. tracks at Franklin. The main relief for this
swamp was afforded by a ditch dug by the camp sanitary detachment into which
400 feet of lateral ditches from the swamp connected. A number of specimens
of Anopheles Quadrimaculatus were hatched out from larvae obtained from this
grassy swamp.

Two abandoned dug wells about 4 feet in area and 15 feet deep found
breeding were filled.
Linear feet of ditching400
Cubic feet of fill350
Labor Costs 18 man days$ 57.60
Supervision8.50
Section 2 Job 6. Franklin District.

Just to the east of the above section were two small areas on opposite
sides of the old Telegraph Road, which were found breeding mosquitoes.
On the west of the road was a half acre stagnant pond which required 850 feet
of ditch and 400 square yards of brush. East of the road a spring fed area
of several acres on the opposite side of the road was ditched off by putting
800 feet of ditch with 500 square yards of brush clearing.
Linear feet of ditching1,650
Brush clearing swuare yards900
Labor cost 30 men days.$ 96.00
Supervision14.00
Section 3. Odenton District.

This area east of the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad and north
of Odenton consisted of a number of constant flowing branches and marshy head-
lands, where though good graces existed much stream cleaning and additional
ditching were required.
Linear feet of ditching3,800
Square yards of brush clearing1,500
Labor 60 man days$ 192.00

Several similar branches and marshes, very important as producers
of malaria spreading mosquitoes were cleared and drained in the section
immediately about Odenton and the Naval Academy Junction. Extensive diffi-
culties were encountered with the railroad culverts and clogged drain tile
lines. Arrangements were made for the Washington, Baltimore & Annapolis
- 24 -
Electric Railroad Company to control breeding in the large pond (maintained
for fire protection), by stocking with top minnows, cleaning the pond edges
and filling of the marshy sections.
Linear feet of ditching2,800
Square yards of brush clearing1,400
Labor Cost 45 man days$ 144.00
Supervision31.00

The ditch to the creek which had been filled from caving in of the
bank was cleaned out and deepened though not completely draining the pond,
The pond was below the water level of the river.
Number of feet of ditching250
Labor Costs four man days$ 12.80
Supervision5.00

A more extensive proposition presented itself in reopening the out-
lets and completing the drainage of the large area north of the Patuxent Station.,
and west of the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks. A ditch 1140 feet long with an
average cross section 4 feet wide and 3 feet deep which had been out along-
side the railroad right away was also damaged by cavings in and filling of the
channel and much overgrown. This ditch was completely reclaimed and the
former marsh at its head cleared and reditched. Two branches going off
into the woods were cleared of brush and rechannelled as far up as found to
contain water.
- 25 -
Linear feet of ditching2,600
Square yards of brush clearing400
Labor 30 man days.$ 96.00
Supervision26.50

A marshy area and several springs west of the railroad were
cleared and ditched, the branch being followed under the railroad and to
the river.
Linear feet of ditching1,250
Square yards of brush clearing280
Labor 13 man days$ 41.60
Supervision6.00
